Purpose: Compare sample mean(s) to population mean or compare means of two samples
Null Hypothesis (H0): No difference between sample mean and population mean or between two sample means
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): Difference exists between sample mean and population mean or between two sample means
Example Use Case: Testing if average height differs from a known population mean

Purpose: Compare sample mean to population mean
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): Sample mean does not equal population mean
Example Use Case: Testing if the average height of a sample differs from the population mean

Purpose: Compare means of two independent samples
Null Hypothesis (H0): No difference between the means of two independent samples
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): Difference exists between the means of two independent samples
Example Use Case: Comparing average test scores of students from two different schools

Purpose: Compare sample proportion to population proportion or between two samples
Null Hypothesis (H0): Sample proportion equals population proportion or no difference between two sample proportions
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): Sample proportion does not equal population proportion or difference between two sample proportions
Example Use Case: Testing if the proportion of voters favoring a candidate differs from the claimed proportion

Purpose: Compare sample mean(s) to population mean or compare means of two samples
Null Hypothesis (H0): No difference between sample mean and population mean or between two sample means
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): Difference exists between sample mean and population mean or between two sample means
Example Use Case: Comparing test scores of a small class to the national average

Purpose: Compare sample mean to population mean
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): Sample mean does not equal population mean
Example Use Case: Testing if the average test score of a small sample differs from the population mean

Purpose: Compare means of two independent samples
Null Hypothesis (H0): No difference between the means of two independent samples
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): Difference exists between the means of two independent samples
Example Use Case: Comparing test scores of two different classes

Purpose: Compare means of two related groups
Null Hypothesis (H0): No difference between paired sample means
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): Difference exists between paired sample means
Example Use Case: Comparing test scores of students before and after a training program

Purpose: Test association between categorical variables or goodness of fit
Null Hypothesis (H0): No association between variables or fits population distribution
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): Association exists between variables or does not fit population distribution
Example Use Case: Testing if gender and voting preference are related

Null Hypothesis (H0): No association between two categorical variables
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): Association exists between two categorical variables
Example Use Case: Testing if there is a relationship between education level and job satisfaction

Purpose: Test if sample matches population with specific distribution
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): Sample distribution does not match population distribution
Example Use Case: Testing if a die is fair by comparing observed and expected frequencies of outcomes

Purpose: Compare means of three or more groups
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): At least one group mean is different
Example Use Case: Comparing average test scores across multiple classes

Purpose: Compare means across single factor with multiple levels
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): At least one group mean is different
Example Use Case: Comparing the average test scores of students from different teaching methods

Purpose: Compare means with two factors, considering interaction effects
Null Hypothesis (H0): No difference among group means, considering interaction effects
Alternative Hypothesis (H1): At least one group mean is different, considering interaction effects
Example Use Case: Comparing the average test scores of students considering different teaching methods and different time slots
Comparing the variability in test scores between two groups
